newsitem.title: USA: Stocks gain on upbeat view of capital gains tax cut.
newsitem.headline: Stocks gain on upbeat view of capital gains tax cut.

text.p: Blue-chip stocks bounced back Thursday as Wall Street put a positive spin on plans to lower the capital gains tax rate.

The Dow Jones industrial average was up 50.97 points at 7,136.62 as it recaptured part of Wednesday's 140-point plunge. At one time, the blue-chip index was up nearly 130 points before profit-taking trimmed the gain.
In the broader market, advancing issues led declines 1,403 to 1,097 on heavy volume of 534 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.
The market's bounce went against conventional wisdom that news of a proposal to make a capital gains tax cut effective as of Wednesday would unleash a wave of pent-up selling on Thursday.
"It was definitely a shock," Jay Meagrow, institutional trader at McDonald & Co. said of the market's action on Thursday. "I didn't see it coming."
After the stock market closed Wednesday, the Republican chairmen of the congressional tax-writing committees said they would propose setting May 7, as the effective date for a capital gains tax.
The tax cut would allow investors to keep more of their profits when they sell stocks.
But lightening the capital gains tax burden also makes investing in stocks more attractive, a view that held the day Thursday, analysts said.
"The demand for stocks seems to be the dominant factor," said Robert Stovall, president Stovall/Twenty-First.
The bond market also helped.

The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose 11/32, lowering its yield to 6.94 percent from 6.96 percent on Wednesday, when the yield rose sharply due to a disappointing auction of 10-year Treasury notes. Bond prices and yields move in opposite directions.
"It adds a lot of octane to the equity market when rates move well below 7 percent," said Guy Truicko, equity portfolio manager at Unity Management.
Among big movers, International Business Machines Corp. jumped 5-5/8 to 167-3/4 after it had an upbeat meeting with industry analysts late Wednesday.
US Airways Group Inc. rose 2-3/4 to 34-1/2 after saying it would cut unprofitable routes and close some facilities in a sweeping restructuring aimed at cutting costs.
Oil stocks gained amid a rise in crude oil prices. Atlantic Richfield Co. advanced 2-5/8 to 145-3/4, Texaco Inc. gained 4-3/8 to 110-5/8 and Chevron Corp. added 1 to 70-5/8.
Petsmart Inc., which runs a chain of pet supply superstores, fell 13/16 to 10-13/16. The company said it expects to report disappointing income for the latest quarter.
The Nasdaq Composite index rose 7.92 points to 1,330.83.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 4.64 points to 820.26. The American Stock Exchange index was up 0.45 to 570.95.
The NYSE Composite index of all listed common stocks rose 1.95 to 426.90. The average share was up 20 cents.
The Wilshire Associates Equity Index -- the market value of NYSE, American and Nasdaq issues -- was 7,745.411 up 38.431 or 0.50 percent.
